Award.AwardTitle: The 6th Midwest Workshop on Control and Game Theory; Ann Arbor, Michigan

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Networked control systems or cyber-physical systems, such as those seen in smart grid systems or intelligent transportation systems, and also e-commerce and social networking platforms, are some examples of societal networks that are widely used in our modern information age. The networked control system methodology has even broader applicability with the techniques and ideas aiding in the understanding of opinion spread in a population or the emergence and prevalence of fads. Conceiving and engineering these systems involves in-depth, inter-disciplinary, and collaborative efforts by experts drawn from controls, game theory, optimization, economics, applied probability and computation. This forms the basis for organizing the 6th Midwest Controls and Game Theory Workshop on April 22 - 23,
2017 in Ann Arbor, MI, where we will be bringing together leading academic experts on controls, optimization, game theory, economics and computation from the mid-western states to foster an exchange of ideas as well as research interactions and collaborations between these researchers.

The workshop aims to promote extensive research discussions, collaborations and open exchanges of ideas among all the participants, and to provide mentoring and feedback to the young researchers in the mid-west. The workshop will host two plenary speakers, fifteen invited speakers from other mid-western institutions, and three invited speakers from the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. All the speakers are leading academic experts in the fields of controls, game theory, optimization, economics, applied probability and computation. They will be presenting their current research work and discussing their research visions. The plenary speakers will also be providing a broader viewpoint of issues and research problems in their talks. The workshop will be open to graduate students and post-doctoral researchers from all the mid-western universities, and these young researchers will be presenting poster and talks on their recent work. The invited speakers list will also reflect the diversity of the organizing committee in terms of involving women and minorities, as also the commitment and efforts of the University of Michigan to promote it. As another refection of the broader scope we will also be targeting an increased overall participation for this workshop from all the mid-western institutions. Strong graduate student and post-doctoral researcher participation will be solicited from all Midwestern institutions, and from all areas in the theme of the workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main purpose project was to fund the hosting of the 6th Midwest Workshop on Control and Game Theory on the campus of the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor on April 22nd-23rd 2017. The targetted goals of the workshop were:

1. To bring together leading academic experts on controls, optimization, game theory, economics and computation from the midwestern states to foster an exchange of ideas as well as research interactions and collaborations between these researchers. 

2. To provide feedback on research from faculty experts to graduate students and post-doctoral researchers.

3. To bring together students and researchers from diverse research groups with overlapping research interests across different institutions, also from the difference campuses within the University of Michigan. 

The workshop had a broader agenda than the past workshops with the topics eing: controls, optimization, game theory, economics and computation (including algorithmic game theory). It hosted twenty faculty speakers (2 plenary from outside the midwest, 15 external speakers and 3 speakers from the University of Michigan) and two poster sessions with roughly 54 posters presented (by graduate students and postdoctoral researchers). All the technical topics (controls, optimization, game theory, economics and computation) were well represented in both the faculty speakers and in the poster presentations. Junior reasearchers (young faculty, postdoctoral researchers and graduate students) had multiple opportunities to get feedback from senior researchers during the workshop. The workshop had a broad agenda and excellent participation (235 registered with 182 attendees) from a variety of departments - Engineering (ECE, ME, IOE, AERO), Computer Science, Economics, Mathematics and Applied Mathematics - and many midwestern universities. Diversity in the participants was strongly encouraged and achieved. In terms of number of women participants was good: 4 faculty speakers, 4 faculty members on organizing committee, many women faculty members, post-docs and graduate students as participants. Undergraduate students from the University of Michigan also participated in the workshop. Industry participation was also there, mainly from Ford Motor Company researchers. In terms of outcomes, the research discussions were extremely fruitful with many new colloboration opportunities arising. At the University of Michigan a campus-wide research community on economics and game theory is being formed that can foster stronger interactions. Details of the workshop including faculty participants as well as their talk titles and abstracts can be found on the workshop website: http://www.ece.umich.edu/events/controlworkshop/  .
